Generalized time evolution of the homogeneous cooling state of a granular gas with positive and negative coefficient of normal restitution

Nagi Khalil IFISC (CSIC-UIB), Instituto de Física Interdisciplinar y Sistemas Complejos, Campus Universitat de les Illes Balears, E-07122, Palma de Mallorca, Spain. nagi@ifisc.uib-csic.es
Abstract

The homogeneous cooling state (HCS) of a granular gas described by the inelastic Boltzmann equation is reconsidered. As usual, particles are taken as inelastic hard disks or spheres, but now the coefficient of normal restitution α𝛼\alpha is allowed to take negative values α∈[−1,1]𝛼11\alpha\in[-1,1], a simple way of modeling more complicated inelastic interactions. The distribution function of the HCS is studied at the long–time limit, as well as for intermediate times. At the long–time limit, the relevant information of the HCS is given by a scaling distribution function ϕs​(c)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝑐\phi_{s}(c), where the time dependence occurs through a dimensionless velocity c𝑐c. For α≳−0.75greater-than-or-equivalent-to𝛼0.75\alpha\gtrsim-0.75, ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠\phi_{s} remains close to the gaussian distribution in the thermal region, its cumulants and exponential tails being well described by the first Sonine approximation. On the contrary, for α≲−0.75less-than-or-similar-to𝛼0.75\alpha\lesssim-0.75, the distribution function becomes multimodal, its maxima located at c≠0𝑐0c\neq 0, and its observable tails algebraic. The latter is a consequence of an unbalanced relaxation–dissipation competition, and is analytically demonstrated for α≃−1similar-to-or-equals𝛼1\alpha\simeq-1 thanks to a reduction of the Boltzmann equation to a Fokker–Plank–like equation. Finally, a generalized scaling solution to the Boltzmann equation is also found ϕ​(c,β)italic-ϕ𝑐𝛽\phi(c,\beta). Apart from the time dependence occurring through the dimensionless velocity, ϕ​(c,β)italic-ϕ𝑐𝛽\phi(c,\beta) depends on time through a new parameter β𝛽\beta measuring the departure of the HCS from its long–time limit. It is shown that ϕ​(c,β)italic-ϕ𝑐𝛽\phi(c,\beta) describes the time evolution of the HCS for almost all times. The relevance of the new scaling is also discussed.

Keywords: granular matter, Kinetic Theory of gases and liquids

1 Introduction

The homogeneous cooling state (HCS) of a granular gas is one of the simplest states of an ensemble of grains that move freely between inelastic collisions. It describes a situation where the system remains spatially homogeneous and its granular temperature, proportional to its total kinetic energy, decreases monotonically in time. Moreover, if grains are modeled as smooth hard spheres with a constant and positive coefficient of normal restitution α𝛼\alpha, for the long–time limit the HCS has two important properties. First, the granular temperature decays in time as ∼1/t2similar-toabsent1superscript𝑡2\sim 1/t^{2} according to Haff’s law [1], and second, the distribution function depends on time only through its dependence on the granular temperature, its scaling form being close to the gaussian distribution in the thermal region and has exponential tails [2, 3, 4, 5, 6]. In addition, the time dependence of the scaling distribution occurs only throught a dimensionless velocity. Similar features are found if grains have different mechanical properties [7, 8], are nonspherical [9, 10], or even if the model includes other details of the grains, such as roughness/rotations [11, 12, 13, 14], or velocity dependent collision coefficients [15, 16, 17].

The first objective of the present work is to complement the existence studies of the HCS by considering negative values of the coefficient of normal restitution (α<0𝛼0\alpha<0). The extension has two complementary motivations. On the one hand, some years ago numerical studies [18, 19] showed that two particles can collide with an effective negative α𝛼\alpha. A natural question then concerns the effect of α𝛼\alpha being negative on the global dynamics of the system. The actual value of the coefficient of restitution depends in general on the exact geometry of the collision, however as a first approximation we can take it as a constant and consider the collision rule for hard spheres with α∈[−1,1]𝛼11\alpha\in[-1,1], a model that can be theoretically studied by means of the kinetic Boltzmann equation and numerically solved with direct simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC). On the other hand, the new possibility opens up the door for a new phenomenology. Namely, one of the main features of granular matter is the indissolubly coupling between dissipation and dynamics: whenever there is a collision, and hence an eventual approach to equilibrium, there is a dissipation of energy, that is the system is also driven by itself out of equilibrium. In the case of hard spheres, when collisions become more and more elastic, α→1−→𝛼superscript1\alpha\to 1^{-}, the relaxation dominates the dissipation, in the sense that the scaling distribution function of the HCS becomes close to the maxwellian. The situation is completely different in the new elastic limit, α→−1+→𝛼superscript1\alpha\to-1^{+}, since now the equilibration mechanism of collisions as well as the dissipation become small (for α=−1𝛼1\alpha=-1 there is no collision at all, i.e. the ideal gas limit).

Despite its simplicity, the HCS is one of the most important states of a granular gas, since it plays the same role the equilibrium distribution plays for molecular gases. It turns out that a general hydrodynamics description for the grains can be derived, in the context of the Kinetic Theory, by using the long–time limit of the distribution function of the HCS as a reference state [20, 21]. However, the aforementioned hydrodynamics has several limitations, with at least two different origins. First, the dynamics of the system has to be such that the long–time limit of the HCS has to be reached by the system in a time scale much smaller than the hydrodynamic ones. This puts some limits to the values of the gradients and the dissipation. In fact, some authors argue that the usual hydrodynamics only applies in the elastic limit α≃1similar-to-or-equals𝛼1\alpha\simeq 1 [21], while others claim that it also works for a wider range of dissipation [20]. Second, the usual hydrodynamics may also fail when describing some steady states of the grains where there is a direct coupling between gradients and dissipation, like in the uniform shear flow. In this cases, it is still possible to derive accurate closed hydrodynamic equations if, instead of the HCS, the appropriate reference state is identified [22, 23]. Interestingly, even though the simplest cases now correspond to homogeneous and steady situations (homogeneous and steady granular temperature), consistency requires that the new reference distribution function does depend on time. The very same situation is found when the system is globally driven by a thermostat [24, 25] and/or a plate [26].

Coming back to the free–cooling case, if one makes an appropriate change of the time variable [27], say τ∼ln⁡tsimilar-to𝜏𝑡\tau\sim\ln t, the dynamics changes so that particles become accelerated while collisions are not affected. At the long–time limit, the dissipation of energy due the inelastic collisions are compensated for by the acceleration, and the HCS becomes a steady state. The change of the time variable maps, in a reversible way, the original system into a granular gas in contact with an effective thermostat [27, 28, 29, 30]. Now we come across an apparent contradiction: the reference state of a gas in contact with a thermostat should be time dependent for consistency [31], but the long–time limit of the HCS is a steady state in the new representation. The second objective of the present work is to unveil the contradiction by reconsidering the time evolution of the HCS in the steady–state representation.

The work is organized as follows. Next section presents the model, its kinetic description, and the steady–state representation of the HCS. Section 3 contains the theoretical and numerical results for the long–time limit for α∈[−1,1]𝛼11\alpha\in[-1,1]. The limit α→−1→𝛼1\alpha\to-1 is studied with some details after a reduction of the inelastic Boltzmann equation to a Fokker–Plank type equation. The time evolution of the HCS is the content of Sec. 4. Finally, Sec. 5 is devoted to the conclusions.

2 Model, kinetic description, and steady–state representation

2.1 The model

The system is modeled as an ensemble of N𝑁N hard spheres in d𝑑d dimensions, inside a square box of volume Ldsuperscript𝐿𝑑L^{d} with periodic boundary conditions. Particles have mass m𝑚m, diameter σ𝜎\sigma, and move freely between collisions. If two particles with velocities 𝐯1subscript𝐯1\mathbf{v}_{1} and 𝐯2subscript𝐯2\mathbf{v}_{2} collide, their new velocities 𝐯1′superscriptsubscript𝐯1′\mathbf{v}_{1}^{\prime} and 𝐯2′superscriptsubscript𝐯2′\mathbf{v}_{2}^{\prime} are

𝐯1′=𝐯1−1+α2​[(𝐯1−𝐯2)⋅𝝈^]​𝝈^,superscriptsubscript𝐯1′subscript𝐯11𝛼2delimited-[]⋅subscript𝐯1subscript𝐯2^𝝈^𝝈\displaystyle\mathbf{v}_{1}^{\prime}=\mathbf{v}_{1}-\frac{1+\alpha}{2}[(\mathbf{v}_{1}-\mathbf{v}_{2})\cdot\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}]\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}, (1)
𝐯2′=𝐯2+1+α2​[(𝐯1−𝐯2)⋅𝝈^]​𝝈^,superscriptsubscript𝐯2′subscript𝐯21𝛼2delimited-[]⋅subscript𝐯1subscript𝐯2^𝝈^𝝈\displaystyle\mathbf{v}_{2}^{\prime}=\mathbf{v}_{2}+\frac{1+\alpha}{2}[(\mathbf{v}_{1}-\mathbf{v}_{2})\cdot\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}]\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}, (2)

with 𝝈^^𝝈\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}} being a unit vector pointing from second to first particle at contact. The coefficient of normal restitution α𝛼\alpha is a number in [−1,1]11[-1,1] and characterizes the amount of energy Δ​EΔ𝐸\Delta E dissipated in the collision as

Δ​E=−m4​(1−α2)​[(𝐯1−𝐯2)⋅𝝈^]2.Δ𝐸𝑚41superscript𝛼2superscriptdelimited-[]⋅subscript𝐯1subscript𝐯2^𝝈2\Delta E=-\frac{m}{4}(1-\alpha^{2})[(\mathbf{v}_{1}-\mathbf{v}_{2})\cdot\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}]^{2}. (3)

Observe that for the same precollisional velocities the energy dissipation is the same regardless the sign of α𝛼\alpha, while the postcollisional velocities are different in both cases. In fact, the two signs of α𝛼\alpha represent two different physical situations: while for α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 we have collisions of smooth hard spheres, for α<0𝛼0\alpha<0 Eq. (3) is a simplification (i.e. gives the asymptotic velocities) of a more complicated interaction that may involve overlaps of particles and/or include a rotation of the contact plane of the two spheres [18, 19]. More clearly, for α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 particles collide elastically while for α=−1𝛼1\alpha=-1 there is no collision at all (ideal gas). One still can forget about the physical meaning of α<0𝛼0\alpha<0, and consider the collision rule as part of a new model of a granular gas that becomes close to the ideal gas at some limit, a limit that has it intrinsic interest.

By definition, the distribution function is normalized to the density of particles,

Very often, the latter quantities are used to characterize the HCS instead of the distribution function itself.

2.3 Steady–state representation

Since collisions dissipate energy for α∈(−1,1)𝛼11\alpha\in(-1,1), the granular temperature is always a decreasing function of time. However, the change of the time variable introduced in [27] and further analyzed in [28] enables the system to reach a steady state. The new time scale does not change the dynamics of the system, but rather represents an useful way of observing it.

Let ν0subscript𝜈0\nu_{0} and t0subscript𝑡0t_{0} be arbitrary positive constants, with dimensions of frequency and time, respectively. We define a new time variable τ𝜏\tau as

τ=1ν0​ln⁡tt0.𝜏1subscript𝜈0𝑡subscript𝑡0\displaystyle\tau=\frac{1}{\nu_{0}}\ln\frac{t}{t_{0}}. (12)

Then, if 𝐫𝐫\mathbf{r} denotes the position of a particle, its velocity defined in terms of the new time is 𝐰=dd​τ​𝐫𝐰𝑑𝑑𝜏𝐫\mathbf{w}=\frac{d}{d\tau}\mathbf{r} which gives

𝐰​(τ)=ν0​t​𝐯​(t),𝐰𝜏subscript𝜈0𝑡𝐯𝑡\mathbf{w}(\tau)=\nu_{0}t\mathbf{v}(t), (13)

that is, particles are accelerated between collisions. Moreover, since collisions are instantaneous, the same rules (1) and (6) apply for 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, after replacing 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v} by 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}.

At the kinetic level, it is convenient to consider a new distribution function g​(𝐰,τ)𝑔𝐰𝜏g(\mathbf{w},\tau) defined as

g​(𝐰,τ)=(ν0​t)−d​f​(𝐯,t)𝑔𝐰𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜈0𝑡𝑑𝑓𝐯𝑡g(\mathbf{w},\tau)=\left(\nu_{0}t\right)^{-d}f(\mathbf{v},t) (14)

which has the same normalization of f𝑓f. Taking into account Eq. (4) for f𝑓f, we get the following equation for g𝑔g:

[∂∂τ+ν0​∂∂𝐰⋅𝐰]​g​(𝐰,τ)=σd−1​J​[𝐰|g],delimited-[]𝜏⋅subscript𝜈0𝐰𝐰𝑔𝐰𝜏superscript𝜎𝑑1𝐽delimited-[]conditional𝐰𝑔\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial\tau}+\nu_{0}\frac{\partial}{\partial\mathbf{w}}\cdot\mathbf{w}\right]g(\mathbf{w},\tau)=\sigma^{d-1}J[\mathbf{w}|g], (15)

where the collision operator J𝐽J is defined by Eq. (5). The fundamental difference of the present equation with respect to Eq. (4) is the presence of a new term in the l.h.s. As already mentions in Refs. [27, 28], the new term acts as a thermostat, injecting energy into the system, and allowing it to reach a steady state, as we analyze in the next section.

3 Long–time limit

Equation (15) has a steady–state solution gs​(𝐰,τ)subscript𝑔𝑠𝐰𝜏g_{s}(\mathbf{w},\tau) describing the long–time limit of the distribution function of the HCS. For α>0𝛼0\alpha>0, the research on the distribution function has focused mainly on two aspects: their cumulants (providing information of the thermal region) and the tails, see for instance [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 28]. In this section, we extend the study to negative values of the coefficient of normal restitution.

3.1 Scaling solution

The steady–state solution of Eq. (15) admits the following scaling form

gs​(𝐜,τ)=NLd​w0−d​ϕs​(𝐜),subscript𝑔𝑠𝐜𝜏𝑁superscript𝐿𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑤0𝑑subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝐜\displaystyle g_{s}(\mathbf{c},\tau)=\frac{N}{L^{d}}w_{0}^{-d}\phi_{s}(\mathbf{c}), (16)

where w0subscript𝑤0w_{0} and 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c} are defined in general as

w0=2​Tm,subscript𝑤02𝑇𝑚\displaystyle w_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{2T}{m}}, (17)
𝐜=𝐰w0.𝐜𝐰subscript𝑤0\displaystyle\mathbf{c}=\frac{\mathbf{w}}{w_{0}}. (18)

with T𝑇T being the temperature associated to g𝑔g (not with f𝑓f) as

T​(τ)=md​LdN​∫𝑑𝐰​w2​g​(𝐰,τ).𝑇𝜏𝑚𝑑superscript𝐿𝑑𝑁differential-d𝐰superscript𝑤2𝑔𝐰𝜏T(\tau)=\frac{m}{d}\frac{L^{d}}{N}\int d\mathbf{w}\ w^{2}g(\mathbf{w},\tau). (19)

Using relations (13) and (14), it is easily seen that the granular temperature is (ν0​t)−2​Tsuperscriptsubscript𝜈0𝑡2𝑇(\nu_{0}t)^{-2}T. In Eq. (16), it is T=Ts𝑇subscript𝑇𝑠T=T_{s}. Multiplying Eq. (15) by w2superscript𝑤2w^{2}, integrating over velocities, and after some algebra, we arrive at an equation for Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}. The solution reads

where ζs∗subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠\zeta^{*}_{s} is a dimensionless cooling rate given by

(21)

For a given value of ν0subscript𝜈0\nu_{0}, the steady–state temperature is a function of the coefficient of normal restitution through ζs∗subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠\zeta^{*}_{s}, not only through the factor (1−α2)1superscript𝛼2(1-\alpha^{2}) at Eq. (21), but also through an implicit dependence on ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠\phi_{s}. Hence, to complete the computation of Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s}, we need ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠\phi_{s}.

The first moments of the scaling function ϕs​(𝐜)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝐜\phi_{s}(\mathbf{c}) are directly given by relation (16). Namely, it is normalized to one, has zero mean, and its second moment is d/2𝑑2d/2. Its corresponding equation can be deduced by replacing the scaling form of Eq. (16) into Eq. ζs∗2​∂∂𝐜⋅[𝐜​ϕs​(𝐜)]=J​[𝐜|ϕs].⋅subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠2𝐜delimited-[]𝐜subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝐜𝐽delimited-[]conditional𝐜subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠\frac{\zeta^{*}_{s}}{2}\frac{\partial}{\partial\mathbf{c}}\cdot\left[\mathbf{c}\phi_{s}(\mathbf{c})\right]=J[\mathbf{c}|\phi_{s}]. (22)

This new equation has to be solved together with Eq. (21), with the additional knowledge of its first moments. Note that we obtain the same equation if we impose the scaling form f=N/Ld​(ν0​t)d​w0−d​ϕs​(𝐜)𝑓𝑁superscript𝐿𝑑superscriptsubscript𝜈0𝑡𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑤0𝑑subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝐜f=N/L^{d}(\nu_{0}t)^{d}w_{0}^{-d}\phi_{s}(\mathbf{c}) to the original Boltzmann equation (4), see [3] for further details.

3.2 Cumulants and tails

Equation (22) has an isotropic solution ϕs​(c)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝑐\phi_{s}(c) that can be expanded in terms of the Sonine polynomials [3] Sn​(c2)subscript𝑆𝑛superscript𝑐2S_{n}(c^{2}) as

ϕs​(𝐜)=π−d2​e−c2​[1+∑n=2∞an,s​Sn​(c2)],subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝐜superscript𝜋𝑑2superscript𝑒superscript𝑐2delimited-[]1superscriptsubscript𝑛2subscript𝑎𝑛𝑠subscript𝑆𝑛superscript𝑐2\phi_{s}(\mathbf{c})=\pi^{-\frac{d}{2}}e^{-c^{2}}\left[1+\sum_{n=2}^{\infty}a_{n,s}S_{n}(c^{2})\right], (23)

Although the expansion breaks down for moderate dissipation [6], useful information is gained if only the leading term is retained, namely S2​(c2)=c4/2−(d+2)​c2/2+d​(d+2)/8subscript𝑆2superscript𝑐2superscript𝑐42𝑑2superscript𝑐22𝑑𝑑28S_{2}(c^{2})=c^{4}/2-(d+2)c^{2}/2+d(d+2)/8. The coefficient a2,s​(α)subscript𝑎2𝑠𝛼a_{2,s}(\alpha) coincides with the first cumulant of the distribution, defined if Eq. (10).

At the leading approximation of ϕs​(c)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝑐\phi_{s}(c), a closed equation for a2,ssubscript𝑎2𝑠a_{2,s} can be obtained from Eq. (22). In addition, if terms proportional to a2,s2superscriptsubscript𝑎2𝑠2a_{2,s}^{2} are neglected, we end up with the following approximate expressions [28, 3] for the first cumulant

and for the scaled cooling rate

(25)

An approximate expression for Tssubscript𝑇𝑠T_{s} is now obtained by replacing Eq. (25) for ζs∗subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠\zeta^{*}_{s} into Eq. (20). See Refs. [32] and [33] for more accurate approaches.

In Fig. 1, the theoretical predictions of Eqs. (24) and (25) for a2,ssubscript𝑎2𝑠a_{2,s} and ζs∗subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠\zeta^{*}_{s} are compared against DSMC numerical results. Numerical results for the third cumulant a3,ssubscript𝑎3𝑠a_{3,s}, as well as theoretical results for the second and third model from [33], are also provided. As it is apparent, the theoretical prediction for the cooling rate ζs∗subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠\zeta^{*}_{s} is very good even for α<0𝛼0\alpha<0. In fact, the important dependence on α𝛼\alpha is given by the factor (1−α2)1superscript𝛼2(1-\alpha^{2}), meaning that the sign of the coefficient of restitution is almost irrelevant for it. For the first cumulant a2,ssubscript𝑎2𝑠a_{2,s}, theory deviates from simulations moderately for |α|≲0.5less-than-or-similar-to𝛼0.5|\alpha|\lesssim 0.5, and notably for α≲−1/2less-than-or-similar-to𝛼12\alpha\lesssim-1/\sqrt{2}. The values of a3,ssubscript𝑎3𝑠a_{3,s} suggest that the origin of the discrepancy relies on the truncation of expansion at Eq. (23) rather than on the assumption of the smallness of a2subscript𝑎2a_{2}, since the bigger |a3,s|subscript𝑎3𝑠|a_{3,s}| the bigger the difference between theory and simulations, in agreement with the conclusions in [6] and [33].

The tails of the distribution function can be evaluated by following the arguments at [3]. The distribution function has an exponential tail for c≫1/(1−α2)much-greater-than𝑐11superscript𝛼2c\gg 1/(1-\alpha^{2}), that is ϕs∼e−A​csimilar-tosubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠superscript𝑒𝐴𝑐\phi_{s}\sim e^{-Ac} where the exponent is given, at the first Sonine approximation, by

A​(α)=2​d​Γ​(d2)Γ​(d+12)​(1−α2)​[1+316​a2,s​(α)].𝐴𝛼2𝑑Γ𝑑2Γ𝑑121superscript𝛼2delimited-[]1316subscript𝑎2𝑠𝛼A(\alpha)=\frac{\sqrt{2}d\Gamma\!\left(\frac{d}{2}\right)}{\Gamma\!\left(\frac{d+1}{2}\right)(1-\alpha^{2})\left[1+\frac{3}{16}a_{2,s}(\alpha)\right]}. (26)

Figure 2 shows a comparison of the latter equation and numerical simulations for a two–dimensional system. The exponent A​(α)𝐴𝛼A(\alpha) have been obtained by adjusting the numerical simulation in the region c≲1/(1−α2)less-than-or-similar-to𝑐11superscript𝛼2c\lesssim 1/(1-\alpha^{2}).

3.3 Loss of unimodality

An important conclusion is inferred from the theory and numerical results shown in Fig. 1. Namely, the distribution functions for the HCS at the steady state for α𝛼\alpha and −α𝛼-\alpha are different, specially if |α|≳1/2greater-than-or-equivalent-to𝛼12|\alpha|\gtrsim 1/\sqrt{2} (the cumulants are quite different). The difference is dramatic for the two elastic limits: while for α→1→𝛼1\alpha\to 1 the distribution function tends to the gaussian distribution (all cumulants go to zero), for α→−1→𝛼1\alpha\to-1 the asymptotic distribution is different from the gaussian (the cumulants are different from zero). This scenario is fully supported by the left plot of Fig. 3 where the scaling distribution ϕ​(c)italic-ϕ𝑐\phi(c) is plotted for three values of α𝛼\alpha, one close to 111 and two close to −11-1.

Figure 3 shows a qualitative change of ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠\phi_{s} for c≲2less-than-or-similar-to𝑐2c\lesssim 2 (thermal region) as α𝛼\alpha decreases. Namely, there is a critical value αcsubscript𝛼𝑐\alpha_{c} of the coefficient of normal restitution behind which the distribution function becomes multimodal. More precisely, if cmsubscript𝑐𝑚c_{m} is the absolute value of 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c} where the maxima of ϕs​(𝐜)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝐜\phi_{s}(\mathbf{c}) occur, then the numerical simulations show that cmsubscript𝑐𝑚c_{m} changes continuously as cm∼αc−αsimilar-tosubscript𝑐𝑚subscript𝛼𝑐𝛼c_{m}\sim\sqrt{\alpha_{c}-\alpha} for αc≃−0.75similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝛼𝑐0.75\alpha_{c}\simeq-0.75, see the right plot of Fig. 3.

The loss of unimodality for α<αc𝛼subscript𝛼𝑐\alpha<\alpha_{c} can be understand qualitatively as an unbalanced competition between the collision–inducing relaxation and the collision–inducing dissipation, as follows. Take Eq. (22) for 𝐜=0𝐜0\mathbf{c}=0, and write it as

J+​[0|ϕs]−J−​[0|ϕs]−d2​ζs∗​ϕs​(0)=0,superscript𝐽delimited-[]conditional0subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠superscript𝐽delimited-[]conditional0subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝑑2subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠00J^{+}[0|\phi_{s}]-J^{-}[0|\phi_{s}]-\frac{d}{2}\zeta^{*}_{s}\phi_{s}(0)=0, (27)

where J±superscript𝐽plus-or-minusJ^{\pm} are the contributions of the collision operator that accounts for the gain (++) and loose (−-) of particles with velocity 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c} around zero. For |α|≃1similar-to-or-equals𝛼1|\alpha|\simeq 1 the term proportional to ζs∗subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠\zeta^{*}_{s} can be dropped and the argumentation simplified. First, take as a reference α≃1similar-to-or-equals𝛼1\alpha\simeq 1: the mean number of collisions that produces a particle with velocity around the origin J+superscript𝐽J^{+} coincides with the mean number of collisions that moves a particle from the origin to any other place J−superscript𝐽J^{-}. For this case, J+superscript𝐽J^{+} involves particles with a wide range of velocities. Now take α≃−1similar-to-or-equals𝛼1\alpha\simeq-1, and assume that J−superscript𝐽J^{-} does not change too much with respect to the previous case, since it depends essentially on the collision frequency. Since 1+α∼0similar-to1𝛼01+\alpha\sim 0 and the distribution function decays to zero very fast for c≳3greater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑐3c\gtrsim 3, the only way a particle around the origin to be created is that it was originally nearby. Hence, the wide range of pairs of velocities of case α≃1similar-to-or-equals𝛼1\alpha\simeq 1 now reduces to a narrow region, that is the distribution function has to be bigger around the origin now.

3.4 The limit α→−1+→𝛼superscript1\alpha\to-1^{+}

The previous qualitative argumentation about the loss of unimodality can be done formally for α≃−1similar-to-or-equals𝛼1\alpha\simeq-1, which has its intrinsic interest. Taking advantage of the fact that ϵ≡(1+α)/(2​α)italic-ϵ1𝛼2𝛼\epsilon\equiv(1+\alpha)/(2\alpha) is very small for α→−1+→𝛼superscript1\alpha\to-1^{+}, the collision operator J𝐽J defined in Eq. Equations (33) and (34) imply that the limit ϵ→0→italic-ϵ0\epsilon\to 0 is singular, that is, the Boltzmann equation for α=−1𝛼1\alpha=-1 (ideal gas case) is different from α=−1+𝛼superscript1\alpha=-1^{+}, since for the latter case the equation reduces to Eq. (33) with a vanishing diffusion term.

4 Generalized scaling solution

In this section, we aim at describing the time evolution of the HCS at a wider time window, and in particular the approach towards its long–time limit. The starting point will be the time dependent equation for the distribution function in the steady–state representation (15). As already described in other works where a similar equation were analyzed [31], a consistent scaling solution to Eq. (15) requires a time dependence not only through the scaling velocity 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c} but also through another dimensionless parameter β𝛽\beta as

g​(𝐰,τ)=NLd​w0−d​ϕ​(𝐜,β),𝑔𝐰𝜏𝑁superscript𝐿𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑤0𝑑italic-ϕ𝐜𝛽g(\mathbf{w},\tau)=\frac{N}{L^{d}}w_{0}^{-d}\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta), (42)

where w0subscript𝑤0w_{0} and 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c} are defined in Eq. (17). If we substitute the scaling form into Eq. (15), we get

[−d​ln⁡w0d​τ+ν0]​∂∂𝐜⋅[𝐜​ϕ​(𝐜,β)]+d​βd​τ​∂∂β​ϕ​(𝐜,β)=n​w0​σd−1​J​[𝐜,β|ϕ]⋅delimited-[]𝑑subscript𝑤0𝑑𝜏subscript𝜈0𝐜delimited-[]𝐜italic-ϕ𝐜𝛽𝑑𝛽𝑑𝜏𝛽italic-ϕ𝐜𝛽𝑛subscript𝑤0superscript𝜎𝑑1𝐽𝐜conditional𝛽italic-ϕ\left[-\frac{d\ln w_{0}}{d\tau}+\nu_{0}\right]\frac{\partial}{\partial\mathbf{c}}\cdot\left[\mathbf{c}\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta)\right]+\frac{d\beta}{d\tau}\frac{\partial}{\partial\beta}\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta)=nw_{0}\sigma^{d-1}J[\mathbf{c},\beta|\phi] (43)

which demonstrates the need of including β​(τ)𝛽𝜏\beta(\tau) in order to cancel out the time dependence introduced by w0subscript𝑤0w_{0}. We have made explicit the new dependence of the collision operator on β𝛽\beta as J​[𝐜,β|ϕ]≡J​[𝐜|ϕ]𝐽𝐜conditional𝛽italic-ϕ𝐽delimited-[]conditional𝐜italic-ϕJ[\mathbf{c},\beta|\phi]\equiv J[\mathbf{c}|\phi]. A convenient election for β𝛽\beta is

β=TsT,𝛽subscript𝑇𝑠𝑇\beta=\sqrt{\frac{T_{s}}{T}}, (44)

which measures the deviation of the HCS (β≠1𝛽1\beta\neq 1) form its long–time limit (β=1𝛽1\beta=1). With this choose, an exact equation for β​(τ)𝛽𝜏\beta(\tau) can be derived from Eq. (42) by multiplying it by c2superscript𝑐2c^{2}, integrating over 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c}, and imposing ∫𝑑𝐜​c2​ϕ=d/2differential-d𝐜superscript𝑐2italic-ϕ𝑑2\int d\mathbf{c}c^{2}\phi=d/2,

{μ2​[β|ϕ]−β​μ2​[1|ϕ]}​β​∂∂β​ϕ​(𝐜,β)+μ2​[β|ϕ]​∂∂𝐜⋅[𝐜​ϕ​(𝐜,β)]=J​[𝐜,β|ϕ],subscript𝜇2delimited-[]conditional𝛽italic-ϕ𝛽subscript𝜇2delimited-[]conditional1italic-ϕ𝛽𝛽italic-ϕ𝐜𝛽⋅subscript𝜇2delimited-[]conditional𝛽italic-ϕ𝐜delimited-[]𝐜italic-ϕ𝐜𝛽𝐽𝐜conditional𝛽italic-ϕ\left\{\mu_{2}[\beta|\phi]-\beta\mu_{2}[1|\phi]\right\}\beta\frac{\partial}{\partial\beta}\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta)+\mu_{2}[\beta|\phi]\frac{\partial}{\partial\mathbf{c}}\cdot\left[\mathbf{c}\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta)\right]=J[\mathbf{c},\beta|\phi], (48)

and has to be solved with the knowledge of the first moments of ϕitalic-ϕ\phi, namely ∫𝑑𝐜​ϕ=1differential-d𝐜italic-ϕ1\int d\mathbf{c}\ \phi=1, ∫𝑑𝐜​𝐜​ϕ=𝟎differential-d𝐜𝐜italic-ϕ0\int d\mathbf{c}\ \mathbf{c}\phi=\mathbf{0}, and ∫𝑑𝐜​c2​ϕ=d/2differential-d𝐜superscript𝑐2italic-ϕ𝑑2\int d\mathbf{c}\ c^{2}\phi=d/2. Once it is solved, the time dependence of β𝛽\beta (and T𝑇T) can be calculated by solving Eq. (45). Finally, this allows us to obtain the original distribution functions g𝑔g and f𝑓f for a wide range of times. Since μ2​[1|ϕ]=12​ζs∗subscript𝜇2delimited-[]conditional1italic-ϕ12subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠\mu_{2}[1|\phi]=\frac{1}{2}\zeta^{*}_{s}, for β=1𝛽1\beta=1, Eq. (22) the steady–state distribution function ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠\phi_{s} is recovered.

4.1 First Sonine approximation

As we did for the steady–state equation (22), in order to obtain an isotropic solution to Eq. (48), we assume that ϕitalic-ϕ\phi can be expanded in Sonine polynomials, as in Eq. (23), with the cumulants being functions of β𝛽\beta. By multiplying Eq. (48) by an appropriate polynomial and integrating over 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c}, equations for the cumulants can be obtained. For example, by multiplying by c2superscript𝑐2c^{2}, we obtain

14​{β​μ2​[1|ϕ]−μ2​[β|ϕ]}​β​dd​β​a2​(β)+μ2​[β|ϕ]​(1+a2​(β))−μ4​[β|ϕ]=0,14𝛽subscript𝜇2delimited-[]conditional1italic-ϕsubscript𝜇2delimited-[]conditional𝛽italic-ϕ𝛽𝑑𝑑𝛽subscript𝑎2𝛽subscript𝜇2delimited-[]conditional𝛽italic-ϕ1subscript𝑎2𝛽subscript𝜇4delimited-[]conditional𝛽italic-ϕ0\displaystyle\frac{1}{4}\left\{\beta\mu_{2}[1|\phi]-\mu_{2}[\beta|\phi]\right\}\beta\frac{d}{d\beta}a_{2}(\beta)+\mu_{2}[\beta|\phi](1+a_{2}(\beta))-\mu_{4}[\beta|\phi]=0, (49)

with

μ4​[β|ϕ]=−1d​(d+2)​∫𝑑𝐜​c4​J​[𝐜,β|ϕ].subscript𝜇4delimited-[]conditional𝛽italic-ϕ1𝑑𝑑2differential-d𝐜superscript𝑐4𝐽𝐜conditional𝛽italic-ϕ\mu_{4}[\beta|\phi]=-\frac{1}{d(d+2)}\int d\mathbf{c}\ c^{4}J[\mathbf{c},\beta|\phi]. (50)

The equation for a2subscript𝑎2a_{2} is coupled to the rest of the coefficients because of the functional dependence of μ2subscript𝜇2\mu_{2} and μ4subscript𝜇4\mu_{4} on ϕitalic-ϕ\phi. However, if the latter quantities are expanded up to linear order in a2subscript𝑎2a_{2} as

μ2≃μ2(0)+μ2(2)​a2,similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝜇2superscriptsubscript𝜇20superscriptsubscript𝜇22subscript𝑎2\displaystyle\mu_{2}\simeq\mu_{2}^{(0)}+\mu_{2}^{(2)}a_{2}, (52)
μ4≃μ4(0)+μ4(2)​a2,similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝜇4superscriptsubscript𝜇40superscriptsubscript𝜇42subscript𝑎2\displaystyle\mu_{4}\simeq\mu_{4}^{(0)}+\mu_{4}^{(2)}a_{2},

with μi(j)superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑗\mu_{i}^{(j)} being known functions of α𝛼\alpha and d𝑑d given in the appendix, and we neglect contributions from cumulants of higher orders, then the solution to Eq. (48) can be written as

a2​(α,β)≃a2,s​(α)+[a2​(α,β0)−a2,s​(α)]​[β0​(β−1)β​(β0−1)]C​(α),similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑎2𝛼𝛽subscript𝑎2𝑠𝛼delimited-[]subscript𝑎2𝛼subscript𝛽0subscript𝑎2𝑠𝛼superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝛽0𝛽1𝛽subscript𝛽01𝐶𝛼a_{2}(\alpha,\beta)\simeq a_{2,s}(\alpha)+\left[a_{2}(\alpha,\beta_{0})-a_{2,s}(\alpha)\right]\left[\frac{\beta_{0}(\beta-1)}{\beta(\beta_{0}-1)}\right]^{C(\alpha)}, (53)

where a2,s​(α)subscript𝑎2𝑠𝛼a_{2,s}(\alpha) is the steady–state value of the cumulant given by Eq. (24), β0subscript𝛽0\beta_{0} is the initial value of β𝛽\beta, and

C​(α)=4​(μ4(1)−μ2(1)μ2(0)−1).𝐶𝛼4superscriptsubscript𝜇41superscriptsubscript𝜇21superscriptsubscript𝜇201C(\alpha)=4\left(\frac{\mu_{4}^{(1)}-\mu_{2}^{(1)}}{\mu_{2}^{(0)}}-1\right). (54)

The exponent is C∼2similar-to𝐶2C\sim 2 for α≤0.5𝛼0.5\alpha\leq 0.5 and diverges as 1/(1−α)11𝛼1/(1-\alpha) for α∼1similar-to𝛼1\alpha\sim 1, see right plot of Fig. 5. In order to be consistent, we should guarantee that a2subscript𝑎2a_{2} is small, which can be controlled with an initial value close enough to the steady value, regardless the value of β𝛽\beta.

As a first application of Eq. (54), reconsider Eq. (45) that we rewrite as dd​s​β=F​(β)𝑑𝑑𝑠𝛽𝐹𝛽\frac{d}{ds}\beta=F(\beta), with F​(β)≃μ2(0)​(1−β)+μ2(1)​[a2​(α,β)−a2,s​(α)​β]similar-to-or-equals𝐹𝛽superscriptsubscript𝜇201𝛽superscriptsubscript𝜇21delimited-[]subscript𝑎2𝛼𝛽subscript𝑎2𝑠𝛼𝛽F(\beta)\simeq\mu_{2}^{(0)}(1-\beta)+\mu_{2}^{(1)}\left[a_{2}(\alpha,\beta)-a_{2,s}(\alpha)\beta\right] at the first Sonine approximation. Since C​(α)>1𝐶𝛼1C(\alpha)>1, it is dd​β​F​(1)≃−(μ2(0)+μ2(1)​a2,s​(α))<0similar-to-or-equals𝑑𝑑𝛽𝐹1superscriptsubscript𝜇20superscriptsubscript𝜇21subscript𝑎2𝑠𝛼0\frac{d}{d\beta}F(1)\simeq-(\mu_{2}^{(0)}+\mu_{2}^{(1)}a_{2,s}(\alpha))<0 implying that β=1𝛽1\beta=1 is a stable fixed point of (45) for all α∈[−1,1]𝛼11\alpha\in[-1,1]. That is, within the first Sonine approximation, the temperature and cumulant a2subscript𝑎2a_{2} always reaches its steady–state values, provided we are close enough to β=1𝛽1\beta=1.

As a second application, we compute the time dependence of β𝛽\beta, and hence that of the temperature. In general, if we use expression (53) of the cumulant with Eq. (45), the resulting equation for β​(s)𝛽𝑠\beta(s) turns out to be highly nonlinear. An important simplification occurs when β𝛽\beta is close to 111, since it is μ2​[β|ϕ]≃μ2​[1|ϕ]similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝜇2delimited-[]conditional𝛽italic-ϕsubscript𝜇2delimited-[]conditional1italic-ϕ\mu_{2}[\beta|\phi]\simeq\mu_{2}[1|\phi], and the solutions β​(s)𝛽𝑠\beta(s) reads

β​(s)≃1+(β0−1)​e−12​ζs∗​s,similar-to-or-equals𝛽𝑠1subscript𝛽01superscript𝑒12subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠𝑠\beta(s)\simeq 1+(\beta_{0}-1)e^{-\frac{1}{2}\zeta^{*}_{s}s}, (55)

where we have used μ2​[1|ϕ]=12​ζs∗subscript𝜇2delimited-[]conditional1italic-ϕ12subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠\mu_{2}[1|\phi]=\frac{1}{2}\zeta^{*}_{s}. The latter expression coincides, after using Eqs. (46) and (20), with Eq. (33) of [28], which in principle is only valid close enough to the steady state (see the comments on Fig. 7 bellow).

Two predictions of the present section, that of Eqs. (53)–(55), are compared against numerical simulations in Figs. 5 and 7. On the one hand, Eq. (53) is confirmed by Fig. 5 for a range of values of α𝛼\alpha for which the first Sonine approximation is expected to work, namely the range provided by the analysis of the steady state, see Fig. 1. For other values of α𝛼\alpha, and if the initial cumulants are not small enough, the dependence of α2subscript𝛼2\alpha_{2} on β𝛽\beta is also given by a law similar to Eq. (53), but with a different exponent C​(α)𝐶𝛼C(\alpha), as Figs. 5 and 6 show. More precisely, Fig. 6 suggests the same origin of the failure of Eq. (53) as that of Eq. (24), that is, the contribution of cumulants of higher order. This is because we observe a data collapse, similar to that predicted by Eq. (53), only if all initial values have the same cumulants (left plot of Fig. 6) but this collapse is absent if the initial data have the same initial a2subscript𝑎2a_{2} but different a3subscript𝑎3a_{3} (right plot of Fig. 6). On the other hand, the theoretical prediction of Eq. (55) is fully confirmed by Fig. 6 for all values of the parameters and initial conditions, meaning that the contribution of the cumulants can be neglected even if the first Sonine approximation fails.

4.2 Relevance of the new scaling

In order to clarify the relevance of the new scaling solution, Eq. (42), to the time evolution of the HCS, let us consider e​(s)𝑒𝑠e(s), a quantity proportional to the number of collisions per particle the system undergoes until time s𝑠s. It can be defined such as d​e=NLd​σd−1​2​Tm​(ν0​t)−1​d​t𝑑𝑒𝑁superscript𝐿𝑑superscript𝜎𝑑12𝑇𝑚superscriptsubscript𝜈0𝑡1𝑑𝑡de=\frac{N}{L^{d}}\sigma^{d-1}\sqrt{\frac{2T}{m}}(\nu_{0}t)^{-1}dt, where we have used that the granular temperature is (ν0​t)−2​Tsuperscriptsubscript𝜈0𝑡2𝑇(\nu_{0}t)^{-2}T. After using the changes of time variables at Eqs. (12) and (46), and using the generally valid Eq. (55), we have

e​(s)=2ζs∗​ln⁡[β​(β0−1)β0​(β−1)].𝑒𝑠2subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠𝛽subscript𝛽01subscript𝛽0𝛽1e(s)=\frac{2}{\zeta^{*}_{s}}\ln\left[\frac{\beta(\beta_{0}-1)}{\beta_{0}(\beta-1)}\right]. (56)

This expression allows us to estimate the number of collisions for the temperature β𝛽\beta and the cumulant a2subscript𝑎2a_{2} to relax to their steady–state values. For the first case, if eβsubscript𝑒𝛽e_{\beta} is the value of e𝑒e for which (β−1)/(β0−1)=1/10𝛽1subscript𝛽01110(\beta-1)/(\beta_{0}-1)=1/10, we have

eβ≃2ζs∗​ln⁡(1+9β0)∼2ζs∗​(α).similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑒𝛽2superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑠19subscript𝛽0similar-to2superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑠𝛼e_{\beta}\simeq\frac{2}{\zeta_{s}^{*}}\ln\left(1+\frac{9}{\beta_{0}}\right)\sim\frac{2}{\zeta_{s}^{*}(\alpha)}. (57)

where we have assumed that β0∼1similar-tosubscript𝛽01\beta_{0}\sim 1, something to be kept in mind for the forthcoming discussion. Let easubscript𝑒𝑎e_{a} be the value of e𝑒e for which [a2​(α,β)−a2,s​(α)]/[a2​(α,β0)−a2,s​(α)]=1/10delimited-[]subscript𝑎2𝛼𝛽subscript𝑎2𝑠𝛼delimited-[]subscript𝑎2𝛼subscript𝛽0subscript𝑎2𝑠𝛼110[a_{2}(\alpha,\beta)-a_{2,s}(\alpha)]/[a_{2}(\alpha,\beta_{0})-a_{2,s}(\alpha)]=1/10, then

ea≃2C​ζs∗​ln⁡10∼2C​(α)​ζs∗​(α),similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑒𝑎2𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠10similar-to2𝐶𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝜁𝑠𝛼e_{a}\simeq\frac{2}{C\zeta^{*}_{s}}\ln 10\sim\frac{2}{C(\alpha)\zeta^{*}_{s}(\alpha)}, (58)

where we have used Eq. (53) for any α𝛼\alpha as an estimation for a2subscript𝑎2a_{2}. If we assume that the time relaxation of the cumulants of the higher orders are at least of order of easubscript𝑒𝑎e_{a}, then we have

ea/eβ∼1C​(α)similar-tosubscript𝑒𝑎subscript𝑒𝛽1𝐶𝛼e_{a}/e_{\beta}\sim\frac{1}{C(\alpha)} (59)

as an estimation of the number of collisions needed for the cumulants to relax in relation to that of the granular temperature.

Let ek∼1similar-tosubscript𝑒𝑘1e_{k}\sim 1 be the number of collisions needed for a dilute elastic gas of hard spheres or disks to relax, an estimation of the so called kinetic stage of the evolution of the granular gas. Then, according to the results obtained so far, we can identify tree different behaviours of the granular gas depending on the value of the coefficient of normal restitution. For α∼1similar-to𝛼1\alpha\sim 1, the time relaxation of the temperature is very big (eβ≫ekmuch-greater-thansubscript𝑒𝛽subscript𝑒𝑘e_{\beta}\gg e_{k}) but ea∼eksimilar-tosubscript𝑒𝑎subscript𝑒𝑘e_{a}\sim e_{k} since C​ζs∗∼1similar-to𝐶superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑠1C\zeta_{s}^{*}\sim 1. That is, for the relevant hydrodynamic time scales (≫ermuch-greater-thanabsentsubscript𝑒𝑟\gg e_{r}) the cumulants take their steady–state values, and with a very good approximation ϕ​(𝐜,β)≃ϕs​(𝐜)similar-to-or-equalsitalic-ϕ𝐜𝛽subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝐜\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta)\simeq\phi_{s}(\mathbf{c}). The situation seems to extend up to α∼0.7similar-to𝛼0.7\alpha\sim 0.7.

For |α|≲0.7less-than-or-similar-to𝛼0.7|\alpha|\lesssim 0.7 we also have ϕ​(𝐜,β)≃ϕs​(𝐜)similar-to-or-equalsitalic-ϕ𝐜𝛽subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝐜\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta)\simeq\phi_{s}(\mathbf{c}), but now due to another reason. As it is apparent from Figs. 1 and 5, for this range of α𝛼\alpha’s it is C​ζs∗∼1similar-to𝐶superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑠1C\zeta_{s}^{*}\sim 1 and ζs∗∼1similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝜁𝑠1\zeta_{s}^{*}\sim 1, so eβ∼eksimilar-tosubscript𝑒𝛽subscript𝑒𝑘e_{\beta}\sim e_{k} and ea∼eksimilar-tosubscript𝑒𝑎subscript𝑒𝑘e_{a}\sim e_{k}. That is, despite eβ∼easimilar-tosubscript𝑒𝛽subscript𝑒𝑎e_{\beta}\sim e_{a}, the system needs few collisions to reach β=1𝛽1\beta=1, and again for any relevant hydrodynamic time scales the HCS is at its steady sate.

For α≲−0.7less-than-or-similar-to𝛼0.7\alpha\lesssim-0.7, the coefficient C​(α)𝐶𝛼C(\alpha) keeps of order one, while ζs∗superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑠\zeta_{s}^{*} becomes big, hence eβ∼ea≫eksimilar-tosubscript𝑒𝛽subscript𝑒𝑎much-greater-thansubscript𝑒𝑘e_{\beta}\sim e_{a}\gg e_{k}. That is, the simplifications of the other cases does not hold, and we are intended to consider ϕ​(𝐜,β)italic-ϕ𝐜𝛽\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta) and β=β​(s)𝛽𝛽𝑠\beta=\beta(s).

5 Discussion and conclusions

In this work we have proposed an extension of the existing studies on the homogeneous cooling state of a granular gas along two complementary directions. On the one hand, the usual hard–sphere collision rule has been generalized by allowing the coefficient of normal restitution to take positive and negative values α∈[−1,1]𝛼11\alpha\in[-1,1]. This way, more complex collision processes have been modeled, as well as new situations of the granular gas, where the relative importance of dissipation and equilibration can be tuned, have been considered. Now, the elastic limit can be reached with α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 (hard, elastic spheres) and also with α=−1𝛼1\alpha=-1 (ideal, collisionless gas). We have tried to realize to what extent the negative values of α𝛼\alpha modify the existing picture for α>0𝛼0\alpha>0. On the other hand, we also reconsidered the time evolution of the HCS, motivated by recent advances on the research of driven granular gases. The study has been carried out by means of theoretical and numerical (DSMC) approaches, both based on the kinetic description provided by the inelastic Boltzmann equation.

At the long–time limit, the relevant information about the dynamics of the HCS is encoded through the scaling distribution function ϕs​(c)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝑐\phi_{s}(c), defined in Eqs. (14) and (16). We have studied their first two cumulants and their tails for all values of α∈[−1,1]𝛼11\alpha\in[-1,1]. Three different regions of the space of α𝛼\alpha can be identified. For α≥1/2𝛼12\alpha\geq 1/\sqrt{2}, we recovered the known properties of ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠\phi_{s}, namely it stays close to the gaussian distribution in the thermal region, hence its cumulants are very small, and their tails are exponential. The region |α|≤1/2𝛼12|\alpha|\leq 1/\sqrt{2} is characterized by an increase of the deviation of ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠\phi_{s} from the gaussian distribution, while the values of the cumulants and exponential tails being almost independent of the sign of α𝛼\alpha. The latter means that, for this intermediate region, collisions have the same effect on the system, despite they are different. This is an example of two different collision rules, but conserving the number of particles and linear momentum, and being associated with the same energy dissipation, give rise to similar global behaviours of the system. Finally, for α<−1/2𝛼12\alpha<-1/\sqrt{2}, we observe an important change of the shape of ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠\phi_{s} with respect to the other two regions: the cumulants take much bigger values and the distribution function becomes multimodal, meaning that its maxima now occur for velocities different from zero, provided α≲−0.75less-than-or-similar-to𝛼0.75\alpha\lesssim-0.75. Within this region, the limit α∼−1similar-to𝛼1\alpha\sim-1 has been studied in details. A simplification of the Boltzmann equation occurs, since collisions induce very small changes to the velocities. That is, not only is the energy dissipation very small (like for α∼1similar-to𝛼1\alpha\sim 1) but also the randomization induced by collision is also very weak (in contrast to α∼1similar-to𝛼1\alpha\sim 1). The new equation, which is of the Fokker–Plank type but with the diffusion and drift coefficients being functionals of ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠\phi_{s}, provides a useful framework where the new phenomenology can be studied. Among many interesting results, we highlight that ϕs∼0similar-tosubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠0\phi_{s}\sim 0 for c∼0similar-to𝑐0c\sim 0, the probability of finding a particle with velocity 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c} being accumulated around |𝐜|=cm𝐜subscript𝑐𝑚|\mathbf{c}|=c_{m} (∼1similar-toabsent1\sim 1 for the two dimensional case). Moreover, the exponential tails of ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠\phi_{s} appear before new algebraic ones. To the best of our knowledge, such velocity (multimodal) distributions have never been observed so far.

The second part of the work has been intended to the time evolution of the HCS for a wider time window. We have shown that a consistent solution to the Boltzmann equation requires a scaling distribution function to depend on two dimensionless parameters ϕ​(𝐜,β)italic-ϕ𝐜𝛽\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta), the dimensionless velocity already present at the long–time limit (c𝑐c) and a new one that measures the deviation of the HCS from its long–time limit (β𝛽\beta). We have provided explicit expressions for the first cumulant as a function of β𝛽\beta, Eq. (53), as well as for the time dependence of the granular temperature, Eq. (55). The former turns out to be very accurate only if the cumulants are small enough, for any initial condition and for all relevant times (after a short transient of view collision per particle). The latter, on the contrary, is of general use. Despite the limitation of Eq. (53), the simulations shows that, in general, the second cumulant behaves in a similar way for any α∈[−1,1]𝛼11\alpha\in[-1,1], which in turn represents an important support of the existence of ϕ​(𝐜,β)italic-ϕ𝐜𝛽\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta).

The possibility of generalizing the results obtained for ϕ​(𝐜,β)italic-ϕ𝐜𝛽\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta), Eqs. (53) and (55), to any value of α𝛼\alpha, allowed us to discuss the actual importance of the new scaling solution in terms of the time the system takes to reach ϕs​(𝐜)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠𝐜\phi_{s}(\mathbf{c}). We have shown that for the relevant hydrodynamic time scales, the new scaling is only appreciable for α≤−1/2𝛼12\alpha\leq-1/\sqrt{2}, provided the initial distribution is close enough to its long-time form. We find this as a very important result that gives support to the hydrodynamic description constructed from ϕssubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑠\phi_{s}. Nevertheless, we consider it necessary to consider ϕ​(𝐜,β)italic-ϕ𝐜𝛽\phi(\mathbf{c},\beta) if we were to wider the range of applicability of the aforementioned description.
